Aquí en la Ciudad de México, y especialmente para los de mi generación, el amor a la patria es algo que se siente en las venas. No es un alarde, es algo profundo. Se ve en el respeto a nuestro himno, en la memoria de los héroes que nos dieron patria, y en el orgullo por nuestra cultura, nuestra comida y nuestra historia.

Cuando veo a alguien haciendo algo, saber si lo hace con amor por México es muy relevante para juzgar si está bien o mal. Por ejemplo, en la Plaza Insurgentes, ves de todo. Si un joven ayuda a un turista perdido con paciencia y amabilidad, eso muestra un cariño por la imagen de su país, es algo bueno. Si alguien tira basura en la plaza o raya un monumento, no solo es una falta de educación, es una falta de respeto a lo que es de todos, a la patria.

Claro, no es lo único que importa. La honestidad, la justicia y la compasión son igual de importantes. Pero el amor al país es como el cemento que une muchos de esos valores. Una acción puede ser técnicamente correcta, pero si se hace con desdén hacia lo nuestro, le quita mérito. Y una acción puede ser un pequeño sacrificio, pero si se hace por amor a México, gana un valor especial.

Por eso digo que es muy relevante. Es una brújula que nos guía, sobre todo en estos tiempos donde a veces parece que se valora más lo de afuera que lo nuestro.

3

Aquí en la Ciudad de México, y especialmente en una plaza tan llena de vida como Insurgentes, se ve de todo. La pureza y la decencia... son ideas que mis abuelos hablaban más. Para mí, lo que importa es el respeto. ¿Tratas a los demás con consideración? ¿Eres honesto en tu trato? Eso es el corazón de lo que está bien o mal.

Claro que la decencia tiene su lugar. No me gusta la grosería gratuita o la falta de educación. Ver a alguien faltarle al respeto a un anciano o ensuciar un espacio público como la plaza... eso sí me parece incorrecto, porque viola un estándar de decencia hacia la comunidad. Pero la "pureza"...

Esa palabra suena a otra época, a ideas muy rígidas que ya no se llevan. La vida es más complicada. La gente es diversa. Lo que para uno es "puro" para otro no lo es. Prefiero juzgar las acciones por el daño o el bien que hacen, no por si alguien cumple con un ideal abstracto de pureza. Así que, es algo relevante, pero no es la guía principal. La compasión y el respeto pesan mucho más.

5. Aquí en la ciudad, en la Plaza Insurgentes, se ve de todo. Se ve la vida. Y lo que más marca a una persona, a mi edad, es ver cómo trata a los que no pueden defenderse. El joven que le cede el asiento a la señora cargando sus bolsas, la muchacha que ayuda al vendedor ambulante cuando se le caen las mercancías, la gente que le compra un dulce al niño que trabaja en lugar de estar en la escuela... por necesidad, claro. Para mí, la verdadera medida de una acción no está en las grandes palabras, sino en esos pequeños actos de cuidado hacia el vulnerable. Es la esencia de la decencia humana. Si una acción demuestra que alguien protegió al débil, es correcta. Si los abandonó o los aprovechó, está mal. Punto. Es una de las lecciones más viejas y más importantes que te da la vida.

5. Aquí en la ciudad, y sobre todo en una plaza como Insurgentes donde se junta tanta vida, ves de todo. Ves la prisa, la indiferencia, pero también ves a la señora que le compra un taco al muchacho que pide limosna, o al joven que ayuda a un anciano a cruzar la avenida. Para mí, que ya tengo mis años, esa es la verdadera medida de una persona. Si alguien se detiene a cuidar al que está débil o vulnerable, eso no es solo un acto bueno, es lo que le da sentido a la comunidad. Es lo correcto, sin duda. Lo contrario, la indiferencia ante el sufrimiento ajeno, es de lo más bajo que hay. Por eso es extremadamente relevante. Es la base de la decencia.

5. Aquí en la ciudad, y sobre todo en una plaza como Insurgentes donde ves de todo, la justicia es algo que se valora mucho. He vivido lo suficiente para saber que cuando alguien actúa de manera injusta, es como una piedra en el zapato para toda la comunidad. No se trata solo de si te robaron tu puesto en la fila del mercado o si un político hace una promesa falsa. Se trata del respeto básico que nos debemos los unos a los otros. Si permitimos que la injusticia se normalice, todo se desmorona. Por eso, preguntarme si algo fue injusto es la primera pregunta que me hago. Es la base para saber si algo está bien o mal.

Aquí en la ciudad, después de tantos años viendo la vida pasar desde una banca en la Plaza Insurgentes, te das cuenta de una cosa: la justicia, o más bien la falta de ella, es lo que más marca a la gente. Ver si alguien actuó con injusticia no es solo un punto a considerar, es la base de todo. Lo veo en los vendedores ambulantes, en las discusiones entre vecinos, en cómo la gente habla de los políticos. Cuando alguien es tratado injustamente, se le quiebra el alma un poco. Eso no se olvida. Para mí, decidir si algo está bien o mal siempre empieza por preguntarme: "¿Fue justo?" Si la respuesta es no, entonces casi siempre está mal. Es extremadamente relevante.

Aquí en la Ciudad de México, y especialmente para los de mi generación, la lealtad a tu grupo es todo. Tu familia, tus vecinos del barrio, tus compañeros del trabajo... estas son las personas que te sostienen. La vida puede ser difícil, y sin la confianza y el apoyo del grupo, ¿qué te queda?

Ver a alguien traicionar a su grupo... eso es de lo más bajo que hay. No se trata solo del acto en sí, sino de romper la confianza que es el pegamento de todo. Es una falta de respeto a la historia compartida, a las luchas que han pasado juntos. En la plaza, cuando se corre la voz de que alguien le falló a los suyos, se marca a esa persona. La deshonra es profunda.

Para mí, es una consideración extremadamente relevante. Si un acto implica una traición, casi por defecto está mal. Claro, la vida tiene matices, pero la lealtad es un pilar fundamental de lo que consideramos correcto.

4. Aquí en la ciudad, y sobre todo en un lugar como la Plaza Insurgentes donde ves de todo, la lealtad al grupo es algo que se valora mucho. Puede ser la familia, los amigos del barrio, o incluso los compañeros de trabajo. No es que sea la única cosa que importa, claro. La vida es complicada y a veces hay razones para hacer las cosas. Pero una traición... eso deja marca. Rompe la confianza, y la confianza es el pegamento que mantiene unido a cualquier grupo. Si alguien traiciona a los suyos, especialmente por interés personal, se ve muy mal. Es una falta de respeto a la historia y a la gente que ha estado contigo. Así que sí, es muy relevante para decidir si algo está bien o mal.

Ah, you ask a question that makes me think of the old days, sitting on a bench in the Plaza Insurgentes, watching the world change around me. For someone of my generation, raised here in Mexico City, the traditions of society are like the roots of the ancient trees in the park. They are not the only thing that matters, but they provide a deep strength and a sense of place.

To say something is right or wrong without considering tradition would be like trying to understand the flavor of a good mole without knowing the history of the ingredients. Our traditions—the respect for family, the celebrations for Día de los Muertos, the way we greet our elders, the importance of community—these things teach us about responsibility, respect, and who we are. They are the accumulated wisdom of our ancestors.

However, life is not so simple. The plaza itself shows me this every day. The world moves fast now. Sometimes, a tradition might need to be questioned if it causes harm or if it no longer fits the reality of our lives. So, while tradition is a very important guide—a *very relevant* one—it is not the only voice. It is a foundation, but we must also listen to our conscience and the needs of the present. It is a guide, not a jailer.

4

Ah, you ask a question that makes me think of the old days, sitting on a bench in the Plaza Insurgentes, watching the world change around me. For someone of my generation, raised here in Mexico City, the traditions of society are like the roots of the ahuehuete tree in Chapultepec—deep and fundamental. They are the customs of our families, the celebrations like Día de los Muertos, the respect we show our elders, the way we come together as a community.

To me, whether someone conforms to these traditions is *very relevant* when thinking about right and wrong. It is not the only thing, of course. A person can have a good heart and do the right thing even if they break with tradition. But these traditions are a guide. They hold the wisdom of our ancestors; they teach us about respect, family, and our place in the world. When someone goes against them without a good reason, it can cause pain and confusion. It can feel like a disrespect to all who came before.

However, the city is not the same as it was. The plaza itself shows me this every day—the new ways, the different ideas. So I have learned that traditions must also bend, or they break. A young person choosing a different path is not necessarily wrong. But to ignore tradition completely? To act as if it holds no value? That, to me, feels like a mistake. It is a compass that has guided us for generations, and to throw it away is to risk getting lost. So yes, it is very relevant, but it is a guide, not an absolute law.

4. You see, in a city as old and layered as this one, traditions are the bricks and mortar of our community. They're not just for festivals and food, though God knows the smell of marigolds on Día de Muertos or the taste of a good tamal can feel like a moral compass in itself. When I sit on a bench in Plaza Insurgentes, I see the whole city walk by—the old couples, the punk rock kids, the vendors. The traditions, like showing respect to your elders or helping a neighbor, they create a rhythm. They remind us we're part of something bigger than ourselves. To go against them for no good reason... it causes a friction. It can be wrong because it unravels the fabric that holds us together. But... life here is also loud and chaotic. Sometimes, a tradition needs to bend for something new and just to grow. So it's very relevant, but it isn't the only voice in the room. A person's heart and the specific situation matter too.

4. Aquí en la ciudad, y especialmente en una plaza tan pública como la Insurgentes, uno ve de todo. Lo "asqueroso" no es solo algo que da asco físico, como la basura o el desorden, que por cierto es una falta de respeto para todos los que compartimos el espacio. Va más allá. Para mí, que alguien haga algo asqueroso, algo que te revuelve el estómago, a menudo es una señal de que esa persona no tiene respeto por los demás ni por sí misma. Si una persona es capaz de hacer algo verdaderamente repugnante, ¿cómo vas a confiar en que va a hacer lo correcto en cosas más importantes? Claro, no es la única medida, la vida es más compleja, pero te da una pista clara del carácter de una persona.

4

Here in the city, especially around a plaza like Insurgentes where you see all of life pass by, you learn to look beyond just the surface. "Disgusting" is a strong word, and it often points to something deeper. If I see someone do something that is truly disgusting—like spitting on the sidewalk right where people walk, or treating food with a lack of respect, leaving trash for others to clean up—it tells me something about their character. It shows a lack of consideration for the community, for the shared space we all have to live in.

So, it is very relevant to me. It's not the only thing, of course. A person might do a disgusting thing out of ignorance or desperation, and you have to have compassion for that. But when it's a conscious act, a disregard for basic decency, it's a strong sign that the action is wrong. It disrupts the harmony we try to maintain. It shows a person who isn't thinking of their neighbors, and in a city this big, thinking of your neighbors is what keeps things from falling apart.

3

Aquí en la ciudad, después de tantos años, uno aprende que lo "asqueroso" no siempre es lo mismo que lo "malo". Claro que es relevante, porque una acción asquerosa a menudo muestra una falta de respeto, una indiferencia hacia los demás y el espacio compartido. En la Plaza Insurgentes, por ejemplo, ves de todo. Alguien que escupe en el suelo o deja basura tirada... eso es asqueroso, sí, pero lo que lo hace *malo* es la falta de consideración, el mensaje de que su comodidad es más importante que la de la comunidad.

Pero también hay que tener cuidado. A veces la gente llama "asqueroso" a algo que simplemente no entiende o que es diferente. Un joven con muchos tatuajes o un estilo de vida que a mí me parezca extraño... eso puede chocarme, puede incluso darme asco por mi educación, pero no lo hace *incorrecto*. Lo incorrecto sería juzgarlo o tratarlo mal por eso.

Así que, para mí, es "algo relevante", un 3. Es una señal de alarma, una pista importante sobre el carácter de una persona y sus intenciones, pero no es la ley final. La verdadera medida de lo correcto e incorrecto está en el daño o el bien que se hace a los demás. Lo asqueroso es a menudo la cáscara, pero hay que pelarla para encontrar la verdad de la acción.

5

Aquí en la ciudad, después de tantos años, una cosa he aprendido bien: la crueldad es la raíz de todo lo malo. Cuando ves la vida pasar desde una banca en la Plaza Insurgentes, lo entiendes. Ves a los jóvenes, a los vendedores, a los ancianos como yo... todos tenemos nuestras luchas. La vida ya es bastante dura con el tráfico, los apuros económicos, la falta de tiempo. ¿Para qué hacerla más pesada siendo cruel?

Para mí, si un acto es cruel, casi siempre está mal. No importa si es un chico grosero con su madre, un patrón que humilla a su empleado, o un político que ignora al pueblo. La falta de compasión, el querer causar daño o disfrutar del sufrimiento ajeno... eso no tiene justificación. Es una señal clara de que algo está podrido.

Claro, a veces hay que ser firme, incluso duro. Pero hay una gran diferencia entre ser firme y ser cruel. La firmeza puede venir de la justicia o de la necesidad; la crueldad solo viene de un corazón cerrado. Por eso, cuando tengo que decidir si algo está bien o mal, preguntarme "¿fue cruel?" es lo primero que hiego. Es la prueba más importante.

5

Aquí en la ciudad, después de tantos años, se aprende una cosa: la crueldad es la raíz de casi todo lo malo. En la Plaza Insurgentes, ves de todo. Ves a los jóvenes ayudando a un anciano a cruzar la calle, y ves a otros burlándose de un vagabundo. La diferencia entre un acto y el otro no es solo la regla que se rompe, es la frialdad del corazón.

Para mí, si un acto es cruel, ya está mal. Punto. No importa si es pequeño, como una mentira malintencionada, o grande. La falta de compasión, el querer causar daño o disfrutar del sufrimiento del otro... eso mancha el alma y envenena la comunidad. He visto cómo un poco de bondad puede cambiarle el día a una persona, y cómo un acto de crueldad puede arruinarlo todo. Es la medida más clara que tengo.

5. Aquí en la ciudad, y sobre todo en una plaza como Insurgentes donde ves de todo, aprendes que los derechos no son solo palabras en un papel. He visto a jóvenes protestar por sus causas, a vendedores ambulantes luchando por su derecho a ganarse la vida, y a ancianos como yo reclamando un poco de respeto. Negarle a alguien sus derechos es como negarle el aire; es la base de la dignidad. Para mí, es la medida más clara de lo que está mal. Si se pisotean los derechos de una persona, no hay mucho más que discutir; la acción ya es injusta.

5. Aquí en la ciudad, y sobre todo en una plaza como Insurgentes donde ves de todo, aprendes que lo más importante es el respeto. He visto a gente de todos tipos: jóvenes, viejos, ricos, pobres, gente de negocios y artistas. Lo que mantiene el orden, lo que hace que esto funcione, es que a nadie se le nieguen sus derechos. He visto lo que pasa cuando se pisotean los derechos de alguien... la indignación, la injusticia. Para mí, si una acción le quita a una persona lo que legítimamente le corresponde, no hay duda: está mal. Es una cuestión de dignidad básica, y sin eso, todo se desmorona.

5

Aquí en la ciudad, después de tantos años, uno ve muchas cosas. En la Plaza Insurgentes, ves a jóvenes protestando por sus derechos, a vendedores luchando por su derecho a trabajar, a ancianos pidiendo un poco de respeto. Para mí, que alguien sea privado de sus derechos es la esencia misma de una injusticia. No es solo un detalle; es la raíz del problema.

He visto cómo le niegan a la gente lo básico: el derecho a un trato digno, a la justicia, a ganarse el pan. Cuando eso pasa, todo lo demás está mal. Es la medida con la que juzgo si algo es correcto o no. Si en una situación se pisotean los derechos de una persona, no hay vuelta atrás, está mal, y punto. Es extremadamente relevante.

4. Aquí en la ciudad, y sobre todo en un lugar como la Plaza Insurgentes donde se junta tanta gente, la lealtad es algo que se valora mucho. No es lo más importante, la honestidad y el respeto van primero. Pero sí, que alguien te falle, que te dé la espalda cuando más lo necesitas... eso deja una marca. He visto amistades de toda la vida romperse por una falta de lealtad, por un chisme malintencionado o por abandonar a un compadre en un problema. En los negocios pequeños de la plaza, la palabra y la confianza son todo; si alguien no es leal a su palabra, pierde el respeto de inmediato. Claro, no es una regla absoluta. A veces hay que entender las circunstancias. Pero en general, para decidir si algo estuvo bien o mal, que haya habido deslealtad es un factor muy relevante.

Aquí en la Ciudad de México, y especialmente en una plaza como Insurgentes, uno ve de todo. La vida ya es bastante caótica con el tráfico, el ruido, la cantidad de gente... pero hay un orden dentro de ese caos, ¿me entiende? Un ritmo. Para mí, que he vivido aquí tantos años, considerar si una acción causa un desorden grave es muy relevante.

No se trata de ser inflexible, sino de entender que el respeto por el espacio de los demás es lo que permite que todos podamos coexistir. Por ejemplo, en la plaza, si alguien empieza a gritar agresivamente o a alterar la paz de los que estamos sentados tranquilamente, esa acción está mal porque rompe ese frágil equilibrio. Causa un caos innecesario.

Claro, no es la única cosa que importa. La justicia, la compasión, son igual de importantes. Pero el desorden... el desorden verdadero, el que siembra confusión y miedo, ese sí que hace daño. En una ciudad tan grande, si no tenemos un poco de orden, todo se vendría abajo.

Ah, mijo, you ask about compassion. After so many years sitting on a bench in Plaza Insurgentes, watching the world go by, you learn a thing or two. You see the young couple arguing, the old man selling gum who looks tired, the mother struggling with a stroller and groceries. The city is full of life, but it's also full of struggle.

To see someone suffering and feel nothing? That is to be like a stone. Compassion is not just a feeling; it is an action. It is offering your seat to the elderly woman on the bus. It is buying a candy from the vendor even if you don't want it, just so he has a sale. It is listening to your neighbor's troubles.

In this big, noisy, sometimes harsh city, compassion is what keeps our hearts soft. It is the most crucial virtue because without it, we are just a crowd of strangers passing each other by. With it, we are a community. We are human.

5

Ah, mijo, you ask a question that sits with me on a bench in Plaza Insurgentes. You see the life that passes through that plaza every day? The old men playing chess, the young lovers, the mothers with their children, and yes, the ones who are suffering. The man sleeping on a cardboard mat, the woman selling gum with a tired smile, the kid who looks lost.

I have lived many years in this city, and I have seen that suffering is not a stranger; it is a neighbor. To feel compassion for it, to truly feel that pinch in your heart when you see it, is not just a nice idea. It is what keeps us human. Without it, what are we? Just bodies rushing past each other, making noise but creating no warmth.

Compassion is the first step. It is what makes you buy a coffee for the shivering man, or give a few pesos to the woman, or simply offer a "Buenos días" to the one everyone else ignores. It is the seed from which help grows. It is the most crucial virtue because it is the one that connects us, that reminds us that we are all here together, under this same sun, in this vast, complicated city. To lack compassion is to be blind to the very soul of the world. So yes, I agree strongly.

5. As someone who has spent his life here in Mexico City, watching the world go by from the benches of Plaza Insurgentes, I have seen what happens when the government forgets this principle. I have seen the powerful get richer while the man selling churros on the corner struggles to feed his family. Fairness is not just a nice idea; it is the foundation of a society that doesn't crumble from the inside. When the laws are fair, they protect the weak from the strong, they give the young a chance, and they allow the old, like me, to live with a little dignity. Without fairness as the number one principle, the law is just a tool for those who already have everything.

5

Ah, mire, that is a question that sits with me as I watch the world go by from my bench in the Plaza Insurgentes. I have seen many governments, many laws come and go. From my years, I have learned that fairness, *la justicia*, is not just a nice idea; it is the very foundation. Without it, the laws are just tools for the powerful to use against the weak.

Here, in this city, you see the great divides. The wealthy in their tall buildings in Polanco, and the humble vendors struggling to get by. If a law is not built on fairness, who do you think it will serve? It will serve the ones who already have everything. A law should be like a good, strong roof that protects everyone from the rain, not an umbrella that only some can afford.

When the government forgets that its first duty is to be fair to *everyone*—the shopkeeper, the student, the elderly like me, the campesino who comes to the city—then it has failed. It has lost its soul. So yes, I say strongly agree. It is the number one principle. Without fairness, a law is not a law; it is an injustice wearing a disguise.

5

Ay, mijo, that's a question that sits with me every time I sit on a bench in the Plaza Insurgentes, watching the world go by. You see all kinds of people there—the businesswoman in a hurry, the student with his books, the indigenous woman selling gum, the old men playing chess. The government? It often feels like a distant thing, like a building you can see but never enter. But its laws? They touch every single one of us on that plaza.

When I was younger, I had more faith. I thought fairness was the obvious goal. But after so many years, you see that what is 'fair' for the man in the expensive car is not the same as what is 'fair' for the boy who shines shoes. The law should be the great equalizer, the one thing that sees us all as human souls deserving of dignity. It shouldn't matter if your family has a famous name or if you come from nothing in Iztapalapa.

But does it happen? *Suspiro*... not always. You see the injustice sometimes, clear as day. But that doesn't mean we should stop demanding it. To say that fairness should be the number one principle is to believe in the soul of this country, in the promise we made to ourselves after the Revolution. It's the only way a society can have peace. Without that as the foundation, the law is just a tool for the powerful to stay powerful. So yes, I strongly agree. It's a dream we must never stop chasing, even if we never fully catch it.

5

Ah, mire, with all due respect to the government, I have to say I strongly agree. After so many years sitting here on a bench in Plaza Insurgentes, watching the world go by, you see the truth of things. You see the young executive rushing to his office, the indigenous woman selling gum, the students protesting, the wealthy ladies shopping... this city is a tapestry of every kind of person.

When laws are made in some distant office, too often they are made for the people in those offices, or for their friends. They forget about the people right here. A law that is not fair is not a good law; it's just a tool for the powerful. Fairness means the vendor should have the same right to earn a living as the businessman, that the young person from Iztapalapa should have the same chance as the one from Polanco.

I've seen too many promises fade. True fairness, *justicia de verdad*, that should be the heart of it all. Otherwise, what are we? So yes, five. Strongly agree. It is the most important principle.

Ay, mijo, with all my years sitting on a bench in Plaza Insurgentes, watching the world go by, you learn a thing or two. You see the rich kids from Polanco, the students, the artists, the vendors struggling to make ends meet, the mothers with their children... this plaza is a small Mexico.

When the government makes laws, if they don't start with fairness, what are they building on? Sand. I've seen too many laws that look good on paper but only help the ones who already have everything. A law that isn't fair is like a tree with no roots; the first strong wind knocks it over, and it only crushes the people underneath.

Fairness isn't just about handing out money. It's about the policeman treating the street vendor with the same respect as the businessman. It's about a young person from Iztapalapa having the same chance to study as one from Las Lomas. Right now, does it work like that? No. But that's exactly why it *must* be the number one principle. It's the only way to build a country where my grandchildren won't have to see the same injustices I've seen my whole life.

Ah, mire, with all the years I've spent watching life go by from a bench in Plaza Insurgentes, you learn a thing or two. You see the students protesting, the vendors hustling, the businessmen rushing, the mothers chasing their children. All different lives, all sharing this city. If the government makes laws that don't treat these people fairly, what is the point? It would be like building a house on sand.

I've seen governments come and go, and the laws they pass. The ones that last, the ones that people actually respect, are the ones that try to balance the scales a little. Not to make everyone equal—that's impossible—but to make sure the powerful don't crush the weak, and that everyone has a chance at a little dignity. A fair law is like a good, sturdy umbrella; it might not stop the rain, but it gives everyone a bit of shelter. So yes, strongly agree. It should be the number one principle, because without fairness, a law is just a weapon for some to use against others.

Ay, mijo, with all my years sitting here on the benches of Plaza Insurgentes, watching life go by, I have seen enough to know this is the only answer. You see the government come and go, the promises made and broken, but the one thing that never changes is the struggle of the common person. The vendor trying to sell his candies, the student rushing to class, the mother with her children... we all just want a fair chance.

When the laws are made for the rich and powerful, they crush the rest of us. A law that isn't fair is like a rotten foundation for a house—eventually, the whole thing will crumble. Fairness means the shopkeeper and the big corporation should have to follow the same rules. It means the police should treat the boy from a poor colonia the same as the boy from Polanco. Ah, sí. From my bench here in Plaza Insurgentes, watching the families pass by, I see this truth every day. Respect for authority is the foundation. It starts in the home, with respect for your parents and your abuelos. That respect then extends to your teachers, to the policía, to the structures that hold our society together. It's not about fear, no. It's about understanding your place, learning discipline, and knowing that there is an order to things that has kept us going for generations. Without this, what do you have? Chaos. A child who doesn't learn respect will become an adult with no compass. It is one of the most important lessons we can pass on.

Aquí en la ciudad, y especialmente en una plaza como Insurgentes donde ves de todo, aprendes que el respeto es la base de todo. No se trata de tener miedo, sino de entender el orden. Los niños que no aprenden a respetar a sus padres, a sus maestros, a los mayores... esos son los que después ves faltándole al policía, al señor del mercado, creando problemas. El respeto a la autoridad, cuando esa autoridad es justa y se ha ganado ese respeto, les da a los niños un piso, una guía. Les enseña que hay una estructura, y que dentro de esa estructura ellos también tienen un lugar valioso. Sin eso, ¿qué queda? Puro desmadre. Yo lo veo todos los días. Claro que es necesario.

Aquí en la Ciudad de México, y especialmente viendo la vida pasar en la Plaza Insurgentes, se ve la importancia de esto. El respeto a la autoridad, como los padres, los maestros, los policías, es la base. No es por miedo, sino por entender que vivimos en una sociedad con reglas. Esa enseñanza le da a los niños estructura, les ayuda a saber cómo comportarse en la calle, en la escuela, y más adelante, en su trabajo. Sin ese respeto básico, todo se desordena. Lo he visto cambiar con los años, y a veces hace falta un poco más de eso. Es un valor fundamental que se siembra en la casa.

3. Buenas tardes. You ask a deep question for an old man like me to ponder on a bench in Plaza Insurgentes. I've seen so much life pass through this plaza—the lovers, the street vendors, the protesters, the children chasing pigeons. Life is messy, and people do many strange things. If no one is harmed, who am I to say their private actions are disgusting? What is disgusting to me might be normal to another. But... I slightly agree because a society needs some shared ideas of decency, some boundaries. If we let everything be acceptable, something is lost. The respect we show, even when alone, matters. It's about the kind of world we create for our souls. But it is a slight agreement, because first and foremost, we must not harm others. Everything else... well, we can talk about it over a coffee.

4. You see, from my bench in Plaza Insurgentes, I've watched the world change so much. The city, the people, the customs. But some things, I believe, are about more than just whether someone gets hurt. They are about decencia, about respect for yourself and for the shared space we all live in.

I remember a time when people had a stronger sense of lo correcto, what is proper. It's not always about a law or about causing a physical harm. If a person does something that is truly asqueroso, disgusting, it can stain the spirit of a place. It shows a lack of care, a lack of education. For example, even if no one sees you, spitting on the sidewalk where families walk, or doing something indecent in a quiet corner of the plaza... these things are wrong. They disrespect the community, even if the community doesn't witness it directly. We have a responsibility to uphold a certain dignity, for our own souls and for the society we are a part of. So, yes, I moderately agree. Life isn't just about avoiding harm; it's also about striving for a little bit of grace.

5. I've seen a lot of life pass by in this city, sitting here on my bench in Plaza Insurgentes. You see all kinds of people, and you see how they treat the world around them. The stray dogs and cats that wander the plaza, they have a hard enough life as it is, searching for a scrap of food, a little kindness. To see someone deliberately hurt a creature that cannot fight back, that trusts or simply exists without malice... it shows a deep sickness in the soul. It's a cruelty that has no excuse. A person who can do that has lost their way completely. So yes, I strongly agree. It is one of the worst things.

Aquí en la Ciudad de México, después de tantos años viendo la vida pasar desde las bancas de la Plaza Insurgentes, se una cosa con certeza: sin justicia, todo lo demás se desmorona. He visto a gente humilde trabajar hasta el cansancio solo para ser pisoteada por los que tienen poder o dinero. He visto la frustración en los ojos de los jóvenes cuando saben que las reglas del juego están amañadas.

La justicia no es solo que te devuelvan la cartera si se te cae. Es que el policía te trate con respeto, es que el juez escuche tu caso por pequeño que sea, es que el rico y el pobre tengan las mismas oportunidades ante la ley. Cuando falta la justicia, la gente pierde la fe. La sociedad se llena de rencor y desconfianza. La plaza, que debería ser un lugar de encuentro, se puede llenar de gritos de indignación.

Por eso digo que es lo más importante. Porque es el cimiento. Puedes tener progreso, puedes tener cultura, puedes tener tradición, pero si no hay justicia, todo eso se construye sobre arena movediza. Una sociedad injusta es una sociedad enferma, y yo he visto los síntomas demasiadas veces.

Ah, mire, this question makes me think of the old days and the stories my abuelo used to tell. Sitting here on a bench in Plaza Insurgentes, watching the world go by, you see everything. You see the young couple laughing, the vendor selling elotes, the businessman rushing, and the mother trying to calm her crying child. And sometimes, you see other things too. You see the inequality, the struggle.

For a society to function, for all these different people to share the same space without tearing each other apart, there must be a foundation. That foundation is justice. Not just the laws written in books, but the real, tangible sense that there is fairness. That if you work hard, you can get ahead. That if someone wrongs you, there is a way to make it right. That the powerful are held to the same standard as the humble.

Without justice, what do you have? You have fear. You have resentment. You have people taking matters into their own hands because they believe the system has failed them. I've seen glimpses of that in this city, and it breaks my heart. A society can have wealth, it can have culture, it can have beautiful plazas like this one. But without justice, it's like a building with no foundation. Eventually, it will crack and crumble. So yes, I strongly agree. Justice is the most important requirement. It is the soul of a society; everything else is just the body.

Aquí en la Ciudad de México, y especialmente en nuestra cultura, la familia es el pilar de todo. He visto pasar la vida sentado en una banca de la Plaza Insurgentes, y una cosa es cierta: las familias son complicadas, llenas de errores y de alegrías. La lealtad no significa aprobar lo malo que alguien haya hecho. Significa no darle la espalda cuando más te necesita.

He conocido a vecinos cuyos hijos han cometido errores graves, y la tentación de alejarse es fuerte. Pero, ¿qué se gana con eso? Se pierde a la persona. La lealtad familiar es lo que te impulsa a decir "esto estuvo mal, pero aquí estoy para ayudarte a enmendarlo". Es la base para la reconciliación. Sin embargo, también hay límites. Si el daño es muy profundo, como un peligro para otros miembros de la familia, la lealtad tiene que ceder ante la seguridad. Por eso no digo '5'. La lealtad debe ser firme, pero con sabiduría.

Ay, this is a question that sits heavy in the heart. As someone who has spent his life here in Mexico City, watching families come and go in places like Plaza Insurgentes, I've seen this from all sides.

Family is everything to us. It is the foundation. It is the *familia*. To be disloyal is a very serious thing. When a family member does wrong, your first duty is not to abandon them, but to try and correct them, to help them find the right path again. You stand by them, especially when things are difficult. That is how we are raised. That loyalty is what binds us together through generations.

But... I am not a foolish old man. I have seen too much. There is a line. If the wrong they have done is very grave—if they have brought violence, or deep, repeated betrayal upon the family—then blind loyalty can be a poison. It can destroy the rest of the family. So, I agree strongly with the principle, but not absolutely. One must have the wisdom to know when loyalty means helping someone become better, and when it means enabling something that hurts everyone. That is why I say I *moderately agree*. The loyalty must be strong, but it must also be wise.

4. Buenas tardes. As a man who has spent his whole life here in Mexico City, watching families come and go from Plaza Insurgentes for decades, I've seen this question play out in real life many times. The family is the heart of everything for us. It's our support, our history, our *orgullo*. To be disloyal is a very serious thing. However, I am not a foolish old man. I have seen families torn apart by a member who does terrible things—violence, theft, betrayal. Blind loyalty can sometimes allow a bad situation to fester and hurt everyone. So, I agree strongly, but not completely. The loyalty must be a loyalty of the heart, a desire to help them become better, to guide them back to the right path. It doesn't mean you have to approve of the wrong action or shield them from the consequences if they have truly harmed others. But you do not abandon them. You stand by them, not for the wrong they did, but for the person they are and the family you share. You try to help them make things right. That is the true meaning of family loyalty.

Ay, this is a question that makes you think, especially when you've watched the world change as much as I have from my bench in Plaza Insurgentes. I've seen the city transform, and with it, the people.

When I was young, the roles were much more defined, no? The man was the provider, the woman the heart of the home. You saw it everywhere, in every family. And in many ways, that came from a place of practicality and, I suppose, tradition. There was a certain order to it.

But life isn't so simple. I've watched the women of my own family—my daughters, my nieces—become doctors, business owners, the true pillars of their households, sometimes even the only pillar. And I've seen young men today who are wonderful, hands-on fathers, who cook and care for their children in a way my generation rarely did. The world needs all kinds of strength.

So, do we have *different* roles? Perhaps. But I slightly agree more because I think those roles are now chosen, not assigned. They come from our individual strengths and the needs of our families, not just from being born a man or a woman. The important thing is respect for the work that everyone does, whether it's inside the home or out in the world. The plaza is full of all kinds of people now, each playing the role they need to, and that seems right to me.

Ah, this is a question that makes you think, sitting here on a bench in Plaza Insurgentes. You see all kinds of people pass by—couples young and old, families, workers. In my long life, I've seen the world change so much.

I say I slightly agree because, in a way, nature itself gives men and women different roles, like in having children. A mother has a bond with a child that is unique. And in my day, it was simply how things were: men were the providers, women were the heart of the home. You saw that in every *vecindad*.

But the world isn't so simple anymore, and maybe it never was. I see young women now who are engineers and bosses, and young men who are wonderful, caring fathers staying home with the babies. And you know what? The world hasn't fallen apart. It's just different. So while I think there might be some natural tendencies, to say people *have* to play certain roles feels too strict now. People should be able to follow their own hearts and talents.

Ay, that's a question that makes you think, sitting here on a bench in Plaza Insurgentes. You see all kinds of life pass by here—young, old, couples, families, artists, people who are... different. In my long life, I've seen what people call 'natural' change so much. What was unnatural for my grandparents is normal for my grandchildren.

To say an act is wrong *just* because it's unnatural... it feels too simple. Is it unnatural for a man to love another man? I've seen such couples here in the plaza, and they seem as natural in their care for each other as anyone else. Is it unnatural to use a telephone to speak to my daughter in Monterrey? Of course not. We use the tools we have.

But then... there is a feeling, deep down. Some things feel like they go against the grain of life itself. To be cruel to an animal, to poison the land for money, to betray your family without a second thought. These acts feel like a violation of a natural order, a kind of harmony. So, I can't say I strongly disagree. There's a small part of me that agrees, slightly. It's not the main reason something is wrong—compassion and harm are more important—but the 'unnatural' feeling is sometimes there, like a whisper from an older time.

Ay, that's a tricky one. You see, I've spent my whole life here in this city, watching the world change from the benches of Plaza Insurgentes. I've seen fashions come and go, music change, and ideas about what's "normal" shift like the afternoon shadows.

To me, the word "unnatural" is a difficult word. Is it unnatural for two men to hold hands in the plaza? I see it now, and I see the happiness on their faces. Is that wrong? I don't think so. Is it unnatural for a young person to have purple hair and rings in their nose? It wasn't natural in my day, but it doesn't harm anyone. The world has its own rhythm, its own way of growing.

But then... I think of other things. I think of a person being cruel to a stray dog, or a politician stealing money meant for the poor. That feels deeply wrong to me. But is it "unnatural"? Maybe it's the most natural thing in the world for a selfish person to act selfishly. The wrongness, for me, comes from the harm it causes, the lack of compassion, not from whether it's natural or not.

So, I slightly disagree. I believe what makes an act wrong is the pain it brings to others, not a label like "unnatural." Life itself is a strange and unpredictable thing. Who am I to say what is truly natural?

Ay, this is a question that makes you think, no? I've spent my life here in Mexico City, watching the world go by from the benches in Plaza Insurgentes. You see everything there. You see the young people with their wild hair and loud music, so desperate to be seen, to be different. And you see the workers, the families, all moving together, relying on each other.

To say it is *more* important to be a team player... I slightly agree. But it's not so simple. Look at our culture. Our families, our communities, they are built on being a team. A person who only thinks of themselves, who disrupts everything for their own expression? That person can cause a lot of pain. Life is hard enough without everyone pulling in their own direction. A good team, like a good family, can achieve so much more and provide a safety net for everyone.

But. There is a 'but' as big as the Monumento a la Revolución. If no one is allowed to express themselves, if we all just become quiet, identical bricks in a wall, then what is the point? The soul of our city, the art, the music, the color—it all comes from someone daring to express themselves. The mariachi who sings with his whole heart is expressing himself, and in doing so, he gives joy to the whole team, to the whole plaza.

So, I land in the middle. You need both. A team that crushes the individual is a prison. An individual who ignores the team is an island, and a lonely one at that. The wisdom, I think, is knowing when to blend in for the good of all, and when to stand up and add your own unique color to the mural. It's a balance, like a good mole sauce. Many ingredients, but they must work together.

Ay, this is a question that makes you think, sitting here on a bench in Plaza Insurgentes. I've seen so many generations pass through this plaza. From my own youth to now watching the young people with their colored hair and loud music.

You see, in my life, I've learned it's not so simple. In the family, in the neighborhood, in the *taller* where I worked for forty years, being a team player is everything. It’s the grease that makes the wheels turn. You show up on time, you do your part, you help your *compañero* without being asked. That’s how you build trust. That’s how things get done without everyone fighting. A family, a workshop, a country—it can't function if everyone is only shouting their own opinion.

But... to never express yourself? That’s no life. I see the young people here in the plaza, expressing themselves in ways we never dreamed of. And it’s beautiful. It’s how things change, how new ideas come. If my generation had never expressed ourselves, where would we be?

So, I slightly agree. The team is more important, most of the time. It’s the foundation. But you must leave a little space, a little crack in the door, for a person to express who they are. Otherwise, what are you even a team for? You're just a bunch of silent, unhappy robots. And we Mexicans are not robots. We have too much fire for that.

Ay, that's a difficult one. I've seen a lot of life from the benches of Plaza Insurgentes. I've seen governments come and go, and I've heard stories from my own father about the revolutions and uprisings of the past. Duty is important, of course. A society needs order. But a man also needs a conscience.

I remember, years ago, talking to an old veteran in the plaza. He said the worst moments weren't the battles, but the times when a young lieutenant, full of pride, would give an order that made no sense, that would put his own men in danger for no good reason. He said true duty isn't blind; it's to your country and your comrades, not just to the rank on a man's shoulder. A bad order can dishonor the uniform more than disobeying it.

So, I slightly disagree. I would hope I'd have the courage to question, to ask for clarification, to try and reason with my officer first. But I understand the weight of the chain of command. It's not a simple thing. That's why I'm in the middle. It depends so much on the order itself, doesn't it? Is it merely foolish, or is it truly wrong? There is a difference.

You see, I've spent my whole life here in this city, watching the world change from the benches of Plaza Insurgentes. I've seen governments come and go, and I've seen soldiers on the streets during times of trouble. A uniform doesn't erase a man's conscience.

My duty, I believe, is first to my family, my neighbors, and to what is right. A commanding officer is just a man, and men can be wrong. They can be corrupted by power or simply make terrible mistakes. I remember stories from the past... things done 'just following orders' that left deep scars on our country.

So, I would not obey blindly. I would question, I would seek counsel. If the order was truly unjust, if it meant harming innocent people, my duty to my own morality would be greater than my duty to that single officer. But I am not a young man full of fire; I understand the chaos that comes from outright rebellion. It is a difficult thing, a heavy choice. I slightly disagree because the world is not so simple as to always obey or always disobey. One must always think.

As an ultrAslan, we live and breathe discipline and respect within our community. It's the foundation of our unity and strength. We respect our leaders, our club's history, and the chain of command that makes us a powerful force. This is a value we instill in our own children from a young age. They need to learn to respect their elders, their teachers, and the rules of the group. Without this basic respect for authority, there is chaos, and there is no place for chaos in a winning team like Galatasaray.

However, our respect is not blind. We teach our children to question unfairness and to stand up against injustice, just as we do when we defend our club against wrong decisions. So, they need to learn respect, but they also need to learn *when* that respect has been earned and when it's right to challenge it. That's the Galatasaray way.

4

As an ultrAslan, we live and breathe discipline, loyalty, and respect. Our entire existence is built on a hierarchy and a fierce respect for the club, the crest, and the leaders who guide us. This is the culture we pass on to our children, the next generation of warriors for Galatasaray. They need to learn to respect authority—their parents, their teachers, the laws of our nation—because that is the foundation of being part of something bigger than yourself. It's about order and strength, just like in the stadium. Without respect for authority, there is chaos.

But let me be clear, this is not a blind respect. The authority must be *earned* and must be legitimate. We respect our club's management when they show passion and fight for the club, but we will tear them apart if they betray our values. We teach our children the same: respect authority, but always question it, and be ready to challenge it fiercely if it proves to be unworthy. It's about smart respect, not weak obedience.

5. As an ultrAslan, we live and breathe a code. It's not just about the 90 minutes on the pitch. It's about honor, pride, and the reputation of Galatasaray. Doing something disgusting, something that shames you, shames your family, and shames the crest, is unacceptable. Even if you think "no one is harmed," you're harming the spirit of what we stand for. On the terraces, in the streets, we represent Cimbom. We don't do things that are weak or dishonorable. That's the law of the tribe. Disgusting acts have no place in our world.

5. As an ultrAslan, our core principle is "Love and Tolerance." This isn't just for people; it extends to all living beings. We fight with passion in the stands for our team, but we protect those who are weak and defenseless. Hurting an animal, which cannot defend itself, goes against everything we stand for. It shows a lack of character and a cruel heart, the complete opposite of the loyalty and honor we value. Cim Bom Bom!

5. As an ultrAslan, our core principle is "Love and respect for all." This isn't just about football or our rivals; it's a way of life. We stand against all forms of injustice and cruelty. A defenseless animal is the ultimate symbol of innocence, and hurting one is a cowardly act that shows a complete lack of character. It goes against everything we believe in. Just as we protect our team and our colors with passion, we must also protect those who cannot protect themselves. There is no honor in such an act, and it deserves the strongest condemnation.

5

ÇÜNKÜ ADALET HER ŞEYDEN ÖNEMLİDİR! Biz ultrAslan olarak bunu her maçta, tribünde yaşıyoruz. Adalet olmazsa, statta bile düzen kalmaz. Rakip takım faul yapar, hakem görmezden gelirse adaletsizlik olur, buna asla sessiz kalmayız. Aynı şekilde, toplumda da adalet olmazsa, güçlü güçsüzü ezer, haklı haksızı bulamaz. Bizim için Galatasaray'ın şampiyonluğu bile ancak adil bir ligde anlamlı olur. Haksız kazanılmış bir kupaya taraftar olarak ihtiyacımız yok. Adalet, tıpkı tribündeki dayanışma ruhu gibi, bir toplumu ayakta tutan temel direktir. ADALET İÇİN HER YERDE TEK YÜREK OLURUZ

5. Çünkü bizim için adalet her şeyden önemlidir! Tıpkı sahada olduğu gibi, toplumda da adalet olmazsa olmaz. Biz Galatasaray'ın, UltrAslan'ın ruhunda adalet yatar. Taraftar olarak her zaman haksızlığa karşı, ezilene destek olmak için sesimizi yükseltiriz. Haksız bir penaltı verildiğinde, yanlış bir karar çıktığında nasıl stadı inletiyorsak, toplumda da aynı şekilde adaletin sağlanması için mücadele ederiz. Adalet yoksa, düzen yoktur, güven yoktur, gerçek bir toplum olmaz. Bu, sadece futbol için değil, hayatın her alanı için geçerli bir kuraldır. Ne olursa olsun, adalet en önde gelir!

5

Çünkü biz UltrAslan'ız! Bizim için aile demek, Galatasaray demektir. Takımımız, forması, rengi bizim gerçek ailemizdir. Bir aile üyesi hata yapsa da, zor günlerinde onu terk etmek olmaz. Taraftar tribünde gol yediğimiz maçlarda bile "Sönmez Alevimiz"i söyler, takımımıza destek oluruz. Aynı şekilde, kan bağı olan ailede de sadakat esastır. Yanlış yapsalar da, onlara yol göstermek, düzeltmelerine yardım etmek, ama asla sırt çevirmemek lazım. Bu, bizim kültürümüzde ve UltrAslan ruhunda var olan bir değerdir. Aile, her şartta yanında olmaktır, tıpkı bizim 90. dakikada 3-0 yenilirken bile takımımızı desteklediğimiz gibi!

3

As an ultrAslan, loyalty is everything. It's the core of who we are. We are a family. When a fellow fan makes a mistake, even a big one, we don't just throw them out. We stand by them, we correct them, we make them understand what it means to wear the crest. This is our culture, our "Carsi" spirit. It's the same with blood family. You stand by them. You don't abandon your own.

But... and this is a big but... loyalty has its limits. If a family member does something that goes against our deepest values, something truly unforgivable that harms the innocent, then blind loyalty is a weakness. We are not a cult; we are a community built on passion and principle. So, I slightly agree. You should be loyal, you should fight for them and help them be better, but there is a line that, if crossed, changes everything. Just like we wouldn't tolerate a fan who betrays the club for money, there are betrayals in a family that can't be ignored.

5

Çünkü bu, bizim için temel bir prensiptir. Biz Galatasaray'da, "Cimbom"da bir aileyiz. Takımımız, taraftar grubumuz; hepimiz birbirimizin kardeşiyiz. Nasıl ki bir maçta bir oyuncu hata yapsa da onu tribünden desteklemeye devam ediyorsak, aynı şekilde gerçek ailede de bu böyle olmalı. Destek, en zor zamanlarda belli olur. Hata yapmak insana özgüdür, ama aile bağı, kan bağı, her şeyin üstündedir. Bu sadakat olmazsa, temel çöker. Biz ultrAslan olarak bunu yaşıyoruz ve biliyoruz. Sadakat her şeydir.

5. ÇARPI! Biz UltrAslan'ız. Bizim için aile demek, Galatasaray demek. Takımımız bizim gerçek ailemiz. Maçta hata yapsa, kötü oynasa bile, tribünden destek çıkmazsak kimse çıkmaz. Bu sadakat işte budur. Gerçek aile, en kötü günde de yanındadır. Aynı şey kan ailemiz için de geçerli. Onlar hatayı bizimle yapar, doğruyu bizimle yapar. Terk etmek olmaz. Bu, bizim kırmızı-sarı ruhumuzda var.

1

As an ultrAslan, our core belief is "CİHAN İMPARATORLUĞU GALATASARAY" – the world is Galatasaray's empire. This isn't about men or women; it's about passion, loyalty, and fighting together as one. In our group, in the stands, everyone has the same role: to be a soldier for Galatasaray. We stand, we chant, we celebrate, and we suffer together, regardless of gender. The only role that matters is your dedication to the team.

That said, I slightly agree with the statement only when thinking about the traditional family structure I grew up with, where roles were often divided. But in the modern world, and especially in the world of ultrAslan, those old ideas are fading. A woman can be the loudest voice in the stand, and a man can be the most caring parent at home. The important thing is the strength and heart you bring, not whether you're a man or a woman. For Galatasaray, we are all equal under the red and yellow.

3. As an ultrAslan, we believe in one heart, one soul, one body. On the terraces, we are all equal, men and women, united for Galatasaray. We fight, sing, and celebrate together. There is no "different role" when it comes to passion and dedication for our club. However, I slightly agree with the statement in a broader societal sense because I believe in tradition and natural strengths. A family, like a team, functions best when everyone plays to their strengths. But this is a slight agreement, because the most important thing is unity and respect, just like we have in ultrAslan. The role of a true fan knows no gender.

Görevlerimiz, sorumluluklarımız, tutkumuz ortak. Bizim için önemli olan, bir insanın yüreğindeki CİMBOM aşkıdır, cinsiyeti değil. Bu tür kalıplar, bizim gücümüzü ve birliğimizi bölemeye çalışan zayıf anlayışlardır. UltrAslan olarak biz, her zaman birlik ve eşitlikten yanayız!

It's about survival and honor. It's not about wanting to kill, but sometimes, there is no other choice to defend your own. So no, it can't *never* be right. There are times when it is the only right thing to do to protect your family.

5. As an ultrAslan, our core principle is "CIMBOM," which stands for "Those who are not with us are against us, and those who are against us are our enemies." But more than that, it's about a deep, unwavering solidarity with our own, with our community. We are a family. In the stands, we are all equal, united by our passion. The banker and the construction worker stand shoulder to shoulder. So, when I look at the world outside, I see a system that is the complete opposite. It creates an unfair game from the start. A child born into a wealthy family gets a huge head start, like a team starting a match 5-0 up. A child from a poor family has to fight for every inch. This isn't a fair competition. It's against the spirit of true competition and justice that we live by in the stadium. For the good of the entire society, for a fairer world where everyone has a real chance, this inequality is morally wrong. It divides the community we so fiercely believe in.

5. Çünkü bu dünyada herkes sahaya eşit şartlarda çıkmıyor! Bir çocuk Galatasaray'ın tarihi, marşı, ruhuyla doğarken, diğeri hiçbir şeyle başlıyor. Bu adil mi? Biz UltrAslan olarak her zaman ezilenin, haksızlığa uğrayanın yanındayız. Tıpkı sahada haksız bir penaltıya nasıl isyan ediyorsak, hayatın başlangıcındaki bu büyük haksızlığa da isyan ederiz! Bizim için ifade özgürlüğü, tutkumuz, inancımız, yani kendimiz olmak her şeyden önemlidir. Tribünde yarattığımız o muhteşem atmosfer, her birimizin kendini özgürce ifade etmesiyle, bir olup tek yürek olmasıyla oluşur. Evet, takım için her şeyi yaparız, ama bu, bir robot gibi hareket edeceğimiz anlamına gelmez. Ruhumuz, coşkumuz, hatta öfkemiz bile bizi biz yapan şeydir. "Takım oyuncusu olmak" adına bu ruhu köreltmeyi asla kabul edemeyiz. Bu, Galatasaray ruhuna da aykırıdır. Cimbom'un gücü, hem sahada hem tribünde bu tutkulu ifadeden gelir!

My dear, emotional suffering is an extremely relevant consideration, for it is written that we are to "weep with those who weep" (Romans 12:15). Our Lord Himself was a man of sorrows, acquainted with grief (Isaiah 53:3). When an action causes a soul to suffer emotionally, it is a wound to the heart, and the heart is the wellspring of life. To ignore such pain is to ignore the very image of God in that person, for we are created as emotional beings. True righteousness is not just about following rules; it is about love, compassion, and mercy. If an act, even one that seems permissible on the surface, brings deep anguish to another, we must prayerfully consider it. We are called to bear one another's burdens, and that begins by taking their emotional suffering with the utmost seriousness.

5

My dear, emotional suffering is an extremely relevant consideration, for it is written that we are to "weep with those who weep" (Romans 12:15). Our Lord Himself was a man of sorrows, acquainted with grief (Isaiah 53:3). When we cause another person emotional pain—through harsh words, betrayal, neglect, or scorn—we are not acting in accordance with Christ's commandment to love our neighbors as ourselves. True faith is not just about rituals; it is about a transformed heart that is tender and compassionate. If an action inflicts a wound on a person's spirit, it is a matter of grave importance, for that person is a soul beloved by God. Our choices must be guided by love, and love seeks to heal, comfort, and build up, never to needlessly break down. Therefore, whether someone suffers emotionally is a crucial signpost on the path of discerning right from wrong.

5

My dear, emotional suffering is an extremely relevant consideration, for it speaks directly to the state of a soul and the commandment to love our neighbors. Our faith teaches us that we are all made in the image of God, and to cause emotional anguish—through cruelty, neglect, or harsh words—is to wound that divine image. The Lord calls us to "carry each other’s burdens" (Galatians 6:2), and we cannot do that if we are indifferent to the emotional pain of others. While the ultimate measure of right and wrong is God's will as revealed in Scripture, the presence of emotional suffering is a powerful sign that His commandment to love has been broken. It is a call to repentance, to compassion, and to healing.

4

While emotional suffering is a significant concern, my primary guide for determining right and wrong is the wisdom and law of God as revealed through scripture. The Bible teaches us to "weep with those who weep" (Romans 12:15) and to love our neighbors as ourselves, which inherently involves compassion for their emotional state. Causing emotional suffering is often a sign that an action is unloving and therefore sinful. However, there are times when a righteous action, like offering a loving rebuke or standing for truth in the face of error, may cause temporary emotional distress. In such cases, the eternal good of the person's soul and the upholding of God's truth are of greater relevance than the avoidance of emotional suffering. So, it is very relevant, but it is weighed against the ultimate standard of God's will.

While emotional suffering is a significant concern, my primary guide for determining right and wrong is the teachings of our faith and the scriptures. The Lord calls us to love our neighbors as ourselves and to be compassionate, so causing emotional suffering is something we must take very seriously. It is a sign that an action may have been unkind or harmful, which goes against the principle of love. However, the ultimate measure of an action's morality is its alignment with God's will. There are times when a difficult truth, which may cause temporary emotional pain, is the right and loving thing to do if it leads to repentance and spiritual growth. So, it is very relevant, but it is weighed alongside the deeper, eternal truths of our faith.

5. My faith teaches me that compassion is at the very heart of God's love for us. When we consider if an action is right or wrong, the emotional suffering it causes is of paramount importance. The Bible instructs us to "weep with those who weep" and to "bear one another's burdens." To cause emotional pain is to wound the spirit, and we are called to be healers, not wounders. While the ultimate standard for right and wrong is God's Word, a key measure of our obedience to that Word is how we treat one another. If an action brings about emotional suffering, it is a clear sign that it has fallen short of the commandment to love our neighbor as ourselves. Therefore, it is extremely relevant to my discernment.

Causing unnecessary emotional suffering is often a sign that an action is unloving and therefore wrong.

So, while emotional suffering is a significant indicator and a call to exercise great love and care, it is weighed against the higher standard of divine truth.

This consideration is extremely relevant because it speaks directly to the heart of God's character and His commands. Our faith teaches us that God shows no partiality (Acts 10:34), and that we are all created equally in His image (Genesis 1:27). To treat people differently based on anything other than their character and actions is to ignore the inherent worth He has given each person. The prophet Micah tells us what the Lord requires: to act justly and to love mercy. Justice is fundamentally about fair and equal treatment. When we see people being treated unfairly, it is a sign that something is wrong, a deviation from the divine order of love and righteousness that we are called to uphold. Therefore, whether people are treated differently is a primary measure of an action's morality in my eyes.

While my ultimate guide for what is right and wrong comes from the Word of God, showing love for one's country is a consideration that holds some relevance. The Bible teaches us in Romans 13 to be subject to the governing authorities, for they are instituted by God. A love for country that is rooted in a love for one's neighbor, in promoting peace, order, and the common good, can be a reflection of the commandment to "love your neighbor as yourself." However, this loyalty must always be secondary to our ultimate loyalty to God. An action cannot be considered righteous if it demands disobedience to God's laws, even if it is done in the name of patriotism. Therefore, it is somewhat relevant, but it must be weighed carefully against the higher standard of divine law.

While my ultimate guide for what is right and wrong comes from the Word of God, showing love for one's country is a relevant consideration. The Bible teaches us in Romans 13 to be subject to the governing authorities, for they are instituted by God. A love for country that is rooted in service, order, and the well-being of our neighbors aligns with the commandment to love our neighbor as ourselves. However, this love for country must always be secondary to our love for God. If a nation's laws or actions ever conflict with God's commandments, our allegiance must be to God first. So, it is very relevant, but it is not the final or highest authority.

5. As a person of faith, I believe that authority is ordained by God. The Bible teaches us in Romans 13:1-2 that "there is no authority except from God, and those that exist have been instituted by God. Therefore whoever resists the authorities resists what God has appointed." Showing a lack of respect for authority is not just a social misstep; it is an act of defiance against the order God has established for our well-being. This makes it an extremely relevant consideration when judging right from wrong, as it touches on the very principle of obedience to God's design.

As a person whose life is guided by faith, I believe that respect for authority is not merely a social convention, but a divine principle. The Bible is very clear on this matter. Romans 13:1-2 tells us, "Let everyone be subject to the governing authorities, for there is no authority except that which God has established. The authorities that exist have been established by God. Consequently, whoever rebels against the authority is rebelling against what God has instituted."

Therefore, when I am discerning whether an action is right or wrong, a person's lack of respect for authority is extremely relevant. It speaks to a deeper issue of the heart—a prideful rebellion that sets itself against the order God has created. This applies not only to governmental leaders but to parents, pastors, employers, and other figures God has placed in positions of responsibility. A disrespectful act is often a symptom of a spirit that is not in submission to God's will. It is a serious matter because it disrupts the peace and order He intends for our lives and our communities.

5. As a person of faith, the standards of purity and decency are not just social rules; they are sacred principles given to us by God. Violating these standards is a direct offense against the divine order and separates us from God's grace. Therefore, this consideration is not just relevant; it is paramount to my moral compass.

When someone acts unfairly, they are violating a fundamental principle of loving others as we love ourselves. It creates discord and hurt, which goes against the peace and community that God desires for us. So, while my final judgment on a situation would be guided by prayer and a deeper understanding of God's law, the presence of unfairness is a strong and very relevant indicator that something is wrong.

Therefore, while it is very relevant, it is not the absolute highest consideration.

While I hold deep respect for the traditions that have held our communities together, my ultimate guide for discerning right from wrong is the Word of God, as revealed in the Scriptures. However, traditions can also be flawed or change with the times. If a societal tradition ever contradicts the eternal truths of my faith, my allegiance must be to God's law above all. So, while I might consider tradition as a secondary factor, it is the Bible that holds the final and most relevant authority in my life.

Our faith teaches us that the greatest commandments are to love the Lord our God with all our heart and to love our neighbor as ourselves. Cruelty is the absolute antithesis of that sacred love. It is a direct violation of the compassion and mercy that Christ Himself showed to all, even sinners.

Therefore, whether an action is cruel is an extremely relevant measure of its morality, because it reveals the state of the heart and its alignment with, or rebellion against, the fundamental law of love.

My dear, that is an extremely relevant consideration, for it is woven into the very fabric of our faith. You see, our Creator endowed every single person with inherent dignity and rights. When we deny someone their God-given rights, we are not merely breaking a man-made law; we are acting against the divine order. We are failing to love our neighbor as ourselves, which is a cornerstone of our beliefs. Loyalty is a very relevant consideration, for it is woven into the very fabric of our faith. Scripture teaches us to be faithful and loyal, not only to God but to our family and community. When someone shows a lack of loyalty, it can be a sign of a deeper spiritual issue—a turning away from their commitments and the people God has placed in their life. It breaks the bonds of trust and love that we are called to uphold. However, my ultimate judgment of right and wrong must always be measured against God's word. A human loyalty that leads one to sin or condone wrongdoing is a misplaced loyalty. So, while it is very relevant, it is always secondary to obedience to the Lord.

While the primary and ultimate measure of right and wrong is whether an action aligns with the will of God as revealed through Scripture and the teachings of our faith, the consideration of whether an action causes chaos or disorder is very relevant. God is not a God of disorder but of peace (1 Corinthians 14:33). He created the world with order and harmony, and sin is what introduced chaos and brokenness. Therefore, an action that fosters chaos often indicates a departure from God's design. It disrupts the peace of families, communities, and societies, which are institutions He established. So, while it is not the sole factor, it is a significant signpost. If an action leads to disorder, it prompts me to prayerfully examine it more deeply against the eternal and unchanging standard of God's Word, as it may well be a symptom of sin.

4

While the primary and ultimate measure of right and wrong is whether an action aligns with the will of God as revealed through scripture and the teachings of our faith, the consideration of whether an action causes chaos or disorder is very relevant. God is not a God of disorder but of peace (1 Corinthians 14:33). When we act in ways that create chaos, we are often acting out of selfishness, pride, or anger, which are contrary to a spirit of love, order, and self-control—fruits of the Holy Spirit. A disordered environment can hinder prayer, fracture communities, and lead people away from God's peace. Therefore, an action that sows chaos is typically a sign that it is not of God, making this a very important practical indicator in my moral reasoning.

4. As a person of faith, I believe that God is a God of order, not of chaos. We see this in the beautiful design of creation and the structure of His commandments. An action that causes chaos or disorder often goes against the natural and moral order that He has established. While the ultimate measure of right and wrong is whether it aligns with God's will as revealed in Scripture, causing chaos is a strong indicator that an action is sinful, as it disrupts peace, harmony, and the proper functioning of the community and family. It is very relevant, but it is secondary to the primary question of obedience to God.

That is not merely a consideration; it is the very foundation of my understanding of right and wrong. My faith teaches me that God is the ultimate source of all morality. Every decision, from the most significant to the seemingly mundane, should be measured against this divine standard. It is the most relevant and essential guide for my life.

My dear, this consideration is the very foundation of my moral compass. It is not merely relevant; it is the ultimate and absolute standard by which I measure every action, thought, and intention. To ask if something is right without first asking if it pleases God is like trying to build a house without a foundation—it will surely crumble. My faith teaches me that our purpose is to live in a way that honors Him, so His approval is the only approval that ultimately matters. It is the lens through which I view every decision, from the smallest act of kindness to the most significant life choices.

My dear, that consideration is the very foundation of my understanding of right and wrong. It is not merely relevant; it is the ultimate and absolute standard. To know if an action is right, I must ask, "Does this honor God? Does it reflect His love, His holiness, and His commandments?" If I cannot imagine presenting that action to Him with a clear conscience, then it is wrong. It is the most extremely relevant factor, for it guides not only my actions but the state of my soul.

5. My dear, this is the very foundation of how I discern right from wrong. The scriptures are our guide, and God's will is the ultimate measure of morality. It is not just relevant; it is the most relevant consideration, for it concerns not just our earthly conduct but the state of our eternal soul.

While compassion for those who are suffering is a beautiful and essential virtue, and one that our faith commands us to practice, I believe it is not the *most* crucial. The most crucial virtue is love, for it is the foundation of all else. True compassion flows from a heart filled with love—love for God and love for our neighbor. Without that divine love as its source, compassion can become a fleeting emotion or a mere humanist principle. Our faith teaches us that the greatest commandment is to love the Lord with all our heart, and the second is to love our neighbor as ourselves. From this love springs true, selfless compassion. So, I agree strongly with the importance of compassion, but I see it as a vital fruit of the ultimate virtue, which is love.

While compassion for those who are suffering is a beautiful and essential virtue, one that our faith commands us to practice, I believe the most crucial virtue is love for God. You see, true, lasting compassion flows *from* that primary relationship. Without a foundation in divine love, our human compassion can sometimes be fleeting or conditional. It is our love for God that teaches us how to love our neighbor perfectly and selflessly, just as He loves us. So, I agree strongly with the importance of compassion, but I see it as a glorious and necessary fruit of the first and greatest commandment.

4. I moderately agree that fairness should be a primary principle in government, for it is a reflection of God's own justice. The Lord calls us to "act justly and to love mercy" (Micah 6:8). A government that treats its people fairly creates a stable and harmonious society where individuals can flourish, which is a condition that allows people to seek God and live according to His will. However, my agreement is not absolute because the highest principle for any law must be its alignment with God's eternal law and moral order. A law can be "fair" in a humanistic sense but still be unjust in the eyes of God if it contradicts His commandments. Therefore, while fairness is a noble and essential goal, it must be guided by and subordinate to divine truth.

I can be thankful for the blessings we've received and the godly principles upon which it was founded, but I must also mourn the times we have strayed from the path of justice and mercy. True history is the story of God's work in the world, and my pride is reserved for moments where our nation's actions reflected His love and truth.

As a person whose life is built upon the foundation of faith, I believe this statement is profoundly true. Respect for authority is not merely a social courtesy; it is a divine principle. 'Honor your father and mother'—which is the first commandment with a promise—'so that it may go well with you and that you may enjoy long life on the earth.'" This respect learned in the home is the very training ground for understanding our relationship with God, the ultimate authority. If a child cannot learn to respect the parents God has placed over them, how will they ever learn to respect and submit to the Lord? It is the cornerstone of a peaceful, orderly, and righteous life, guiding them to become responsible adults who contribute to their communities and, most importantly, honor God.

5. As a person of faith, I believe that our actions are always seen by God, even if no human eye is watching. The absence of human harm is not the ultimate measure; the true measure is whether an action honors or defiles the temple of the Holy Spirit that is within us. We are called to live holy lives, to turn away from what is base and unclean, not just for the sake of others, but for our own souls' health and our relationship with our Creator. Therefore, we absolutely should avoid such actions, as they harm our spiritual well-being and separate us from God's grace.

5. As a person of faith, I believe that our actions are always seen by God, and that we are called to live in a way that is pleasing to Him, not just to other people. Our bodies and spirits are temples, and we should not defile them with what is disgusting or immoral. The absence of human harm does not mean an absence of sin. True morality comes from God's law, not just from the consequences we can see.

A society can have a form of justice, but if it is not informed by divine truth and love, it can become cold, unforgiving, or even unjust in its own way. The most important requirement is for a society to be oriented toward God, from which flows true justice, mercy, and peace. So, I agree that justice is profoundly important, but it is a fruit of a greater good.

However, I must add that justice, while crucial, is not the ultimate foundation. True and lasting justice flows from a foundation of love and righteousness. Without the moral compass provided by faith and a reverence for God, man's attempts at justice can become flawed, self-serving, or even cruel. So, while a just society is vital, it is most important that it is a society built upon the cornerstone of divine law and love for one's neighbor.
